However, another alternative study for diagnosing uncomplicated acute cholecystitis is indicated prior to CT.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI is an alternative imaging modality used to diagnose acute cholecystitis in patients who have inconclusive ultrasound results. MRI is especially useful for those who have a contraindication to CT scan (e.g., pregnancy, contrast allergy). However, another alternative study for diagnosing uncomplicated acute cholecystitis is indicated prior to MRI.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical presentation (long-lasting postprandial abdominal pain, nausea, RUQ tenderness) in combination with her laboratory findings (leukocytosis, mildly elevated ALP, AST, and ALT) suggests acute cholecystitis. Since abdominal ultrasound findings were inconclusive, a different test is needed to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of increasingly severe right upper abdominal pain, fever, and nonbloody vomiting for 5 hours. The pain is dull and intermittent and radiates to her right shoulder. During the past 3 months, she had recurring abdominal discomfort after meals. She is 171 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 99 kg (218 lb); BMI is 35 kg/m2. Abdominal examination shows right upper quadrant abdominal tenderness and guarding. Upon deep palpation of the right upper quadrant, the patient pauses during inspiration. An x-ray of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Further evaluation of the patient is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: History of recent travel to Indonesia
History of recurrent sexually transmitted infections
Frequent, high-pitched bowel sounds on auscultation

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A history of multiparity is a significant risk factor for gallstones, which account for 90–95% of cases of acute cholecystitis. The risk of gallstone disease is about 10 times greater among multiparous women than nulliparous women. Higher estrogen levels during pregnancy increase the secretion of cholesterol into bile, while higher progesterone levels decrease the production of hydrophilic bile acids, resulting in a decreased ability of bile to sequester cholesterol. The combination of these effects leads to the supersaturation of bile with cholesterol, which in turn predisposes the patient to gallstone disease.

Key learning point: Multiparity is a significant risk factor for gallstone formation and acute cholecystitis due to hormonal changes during pregnancy that promote bile cholesterol supersaturation.

B) INCORRECT:

Carbohydrate deficient transferrin (CDT) levels are typically increased in patients with heavy alcohol use. Acute pancreatitis, which is caused by alcohol consumption in approx. 30% of cases, would present similarly, with abdominal pain, vomiting, and low-grade fever. However, the localization of pain to the right upper quadrant and right shoulder as well as the positive Murphy sign suggest that the diagnosis is more likely to be acute cholecystitis than acute pancreatitis. 90–95% of cases of acute cholecystitis are caused by gallstone disease. However, alcohol consumption is not a direct risk factor for gallstone disease. In fact, mild to moderate consumption of alcohol decreases the risk of gallstone disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Indonesia is an endemic region for hepatitis A, with a seroprevalence among adults of about 90%. Most cases of hepatitis A in the US occur in patients who have traveled to endemic countries. Patients with hepatitis A can develop right upper quadrant pain and tenderness (due to swelling of the liver and stretching of the Glisson capsule), vomiting, and fever. However, the presence of referred pain in the right shoulder and a positive Murphy sign is consistent with a diagnosis of acute cholecystitis, which is caused by gallstones in 90–95% of cases. Hepatitis A infection is not known to increase the risk of gallstone disease. Patients with acute hepatitis A infection typically have severe jaundice and high serum transaminase levels (AST levels are usually > 20 times the normal upper limit).

D) INCORRECT:

Recurrent infection with sexually transmitted organisms, such as C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhea, can result in pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome, which occurs as a complication in 12–14% of PID cases, can closely resemble acute cholecystitis, manifesting with right upper quadrant pain, fever, vomiting, and even referred pain in the right shoulder. However, the absence of a history of PID symptoms (e.g., pelvic pain, infertility) and a positive Murphy sign suggest acute cholecystitis, which is caused by gallstones in 90–95% of cases. Sexually transmitted infections are not known to cause gallstone disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Frequent, high-pitched bowel sounds might indicate mechanical bowel obstruction. However, acute cholecystitis, which may result in peritonitis, would present with absent bowel sounds due to paralytic ileus, and not mechanical bowel obstruction. One to four percent of cases of mechanical bowel obstruction are caused by a large gallstone within the small intestine (gallstone ileus), in which case frequent, high-pitched bowel sounds would be present. However, gallstone ileus is a rare complication of gallstone disease (0.5% of cases). Moreover, an abdominal x-ray in patients with gallstone ileus would show air within the biliary tree. A normal abdominal x-ray with no evidence of pneumobilia suggests that this patient does not have gallstone ileus.
Image Description:

Cholecystoenteric fistula is an abnormal connection between the gallbladder lumen and the adjacent bowel (usually duodenum or stomach). The fistula creates a conduit for the passage of gallstones from the gallbladder into the bowel and for air from the bowel into the biliary system (i.e., pneumobilia), which can be seen on imaging.

Large gallstones can become lodged in the distal ileum (most commonly the ileocecal valve), causing gallstone ileus. Radiographic imaging typically shows signs of mechanical obstruction (distended bowel loops proximal to the obstruction) and the gallstone.
questions.hint: This patient presents with RUQ pain radiating to her right shoulder, fever, a history of abdominal discomfort after meals, and a positive Murphy sign, suggesting acute cholecystitis that is likely secondary to gallstones. What is the mnemonic for the risk factors of cholelithiasis again? Female, Fat, Forty, Fair-skinned, Family history and F.…

questions.text: Three days after undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery, a 72-year-old man has severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, benign prostatic hyperplasia, peripheral vascular disease, and chronic mesenteric ischemia. Abdominal examination shows a soft abdomen with tenderness and sudden inspiratory arrest upon palpation in the right upper quadrant. There is no rebound tenderness or guarding. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis. Abdominal ultrasonography shows a distended gallbladder, thickened gallbladder wall with pericholecystic fluid, and no stones. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Intravenous heparin therapy followed by embolectomy
Careful observation with serial abdominal examinations
Intravenous piperacillin-tazobactam therapy and percutaneous cholecystostomy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous heparin therapy followed by embolectomy can be performed to treat embolic diseases such as acute mesenteric ischemia, which manifests with abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting as seen in this patient. However, acute mesenteric ischemia would not explain this patient's findings on abdominal ultrasound, which are more consistent with acalculous cholecystitis and warrant a different treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Observation with serial examinations may be appropriate for diseases that have the potential to resolve on their own without complications. This patient with acalculous cholecystitis is at high risk of gallbladder perforation and rapid deterioration. He should receive appropriate treatment as soon as possible.

C) INCORRECT:

Cholecystectomy is the definitive treatment of acalculous cholecystitis. However, in severely ill patients such as this one, another less invasive procedure should first be conducted. If the patient does not improve within 24 hours after initial treatment, cholecystectomy should be performed.

D) CORRECT:

Acalculous cholecystitis puts this patient at high risk of gallbladder perforation and rapid deterioration. Apart from fluid resuscitation, he should be started on broad-spectrum antibiotics such as piperacillin-tazobactam immediately, and cholecystostomy should be performed to decompress his distended gallbladder. Cholecystectomy is the definitive treatment for acalculous cholecystitis. A percutaneous cholecystostomy, on the other hand, is a less invasive temporizing alternative for severely ill patients (such as this patient, who has several severe diseases and has recently undergone a major surgical procedure) or patients too unstable to be under general anesthesia. If the patient does not improve within 24 hours, a cholecystectomy should be performed.

E) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with papillotomy and placement of a stent between the gallbladder and the duodenum to decompress the gallbladder can be performed as a palliative treatment in patients with acalculous cholecystitis who are high-risk surgical candidates. However, in this patient, curative treatment is indicated.
questions.hint: This patient's fever, right upper quadrant pain, positive Murphy sign, and ultrasound findings of a distended gallbladder with thickened wall and pericholecystic fluid are consistent with acute cholecystitis. Considering that he has several illnesses, has recently undergone a major surgical procedure, and that there is no evidence of stones in the gallbladder, he likely has acute acalculous cholecystitis.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old man is in the Intensive Care Unit following emergency surgery for a perforated colon. Over the past 48 hours, he has developed persistent right upper quadrant tenderness, low-grade fevers, and a rising white blood cell count from 9.0 × 10^9/L to 16.4 × 10^9/L. He is hemodynamically fragile, and repeat CT scanning shows no new intra-abdominal abscesses. Blood cultures are negative, but intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics have been continued. He is currently too unstable to undergo general anesthesia (see lab result and reports).


Test
Result
Normal Values


WBC
16.4 x 10⁹/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 10⁹/L



Abdominal ultrasound: Distended gallbladder with thickened walls, pericholecystic fluid, and biliary sludge without identifiable stones
CT scan: No new intra-abdominal abscesses

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acalculous cholecystitis manifests in critically ill patients due to ischemia, bile stasis, and sepsis, even without gallstones. Ultrasound findings of a distended gallbladder with wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid, and biliary sludge confirm the diagnosis. In hemodynamically unstable patients, ultrasound-guided percutaneous cholecystostomy is a minimally invasive procedure that decompresses the gallbladder, providing effective source control and stabilization without the risks of general anesthesia.

Key learning point: In critically ill patients with acute acalculous cholecystitis, US-guided tube cholecystostomy drainage is preferred over surgical cholecystectomy due to lower procedural risk.

B) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the definitive treatment for cholecystitis in stable patients. However, this patient is critically ill and hemodynamically unstable, making general anesthesia and surgery too risky. The recent major surgery and potential postoperative adhesions further increase the risk of complications.

C) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is used for biliary tree and pancreatic duct issues, such as choledocholithiasis or cholangitis. This patient has gallbladder inflammation without ductal obstruction, making ERCP inappropriate. Additionally, the patient's hemodynamic instability makes the sedation and procedural risks of ERCP unfavorable.

D) INCORRECT:

While antibiotics are crucial for systemic infection control, they do not address the localized inflammation in acalculous cholecystitis. The ultrasound findings indicate the need for gallbladder decompression. Antibiotics alone are insufficient for source control, especially in a hemodynamically unstable patient.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with 2 days of severe right upper quadrant pain that started after a large fatty meal. She has had intermittent fevers and chills. She denies any previous episodes and is otherwise healthy. She has no significant medical or surgical history. Examination shows a positive Murphy sign. She has mild nausea but no vomiting (see lab result and report).


Heart rate
92/min


Blood pressure
118/76 mmHg


Temperature
38.3°C




Test
Result
Normal Values


WBC
12.4 x 10⁹/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 10⁹/L


Right upper quadrant ultrasound: Gallbladder wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid, and a 10-mm gallstone lodged in the gallbladder neck
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Intravenous antibiotics alone until symptoms improve

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous cholecystostomy is reserved for patients with acute cholecystitis who are not surgical candidates due to significant comorbidities or instability. This patient is young, healthy, and stable, with no contraindications to surgery, making percutaneous cholecystostomy unnecessary.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous antibiotics are crucial for managing infection in acute cholecystitis, but they do not address the obstructing gallstone. In young, healthy patients with definitive imaging findings of calculous cholecystitis, antibiotics alone are insufficient. The persistent stone poses a risk for recurrent episodes or complications, necessitating surgical intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Delayed laparoscopic cholecystectomy is considered when initial conservative management is chosen for mild symptoms or when immediate surgery is not feasible. This patient has acute cholecystitis with systemic inflammation and obstructing gallstone, warranting prompt surgical intervention to prevent complications.

D) CORRECT:

Acute calculous cholecystitis is caused by a gallstone obstructing the cystic duct, leading to bile stasis and inflammation. Ultrasound findings of gallbladder wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid, and a lodged stone confirm the diagnosis. Early laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the preferred treatment for medically stable patients, as it addresses the underlying cause, reduces the risk of complications like gangrene or perforation, and prevents future episodes. This minimally invasive approach offers benefits such as quicker recovery and shorter hospital stay, aligning with current clinical guidelines favoring prompt surgical intervention.

Key learning point: Early laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the preferred management for acute cholecystitis due to its benefits of shorter recovery time and fewer complications compared to delayed surgery.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man presents with acute-onset, severe epigastric pain radiating to the back for the past 10 hours. He reports several episodes of vomiting and has not tolerated oral intake. His urine output has decreased over the last 6 hours. Physical examination shows marked epigastric tenderness without peritonitis (see lab results and report).


Heart rate
110/min


Blood pressure
95/58 mmHg


Oxygen saturation
98%




Test
Result
Normal Values



Lipase
4000 IU/L
0 - 160 IU/L


Alanine aminotransferase
95 IU/L
5 - 40 IU/L



Abdominal ultrasound: Gallstones; no biliary dilation
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics are not routinely indicated in acute pancreatitis unless there is evidence of infected necrosis or overt biliary infection. This patient has gallstone-related pancreatitis with elevated lipase and gallstones on ultrasound, but no biliary dilation or signs of infection, such as cholangitis. The mild elevation in alanine aminotransferase and hemodynamic instability are more consistent with volume depletion than sepsis.

B) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is indicated for biliary obstruction or cholangitis. This patient has gallstones but no biliary dilation or significant cholestasis, reducing the likelihood of obstruction or cholangitis. The clinical focus should be on supportive care rather than procedural intervention, as the conditions for urgent ERCP are not met.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with acute pancreatitis, indicated by severe epigastric pain radiating to the back, elevated lipase levels, tachycardia, hypotension, and decreased urine output. These findings suggest hemodynamic instability due to significant intravascular fluid losses from third spacing and systemic inflammation. Aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation with crystalloids, such as lactated Ringer’s solution, is crucial to restore intravascular volume, stabilize hemodynamics, and optimize pancreatic perfusion. Early fluid management is essential to mitigate pancreatic injury severity and improve outcomes in acute pancreatitis.

Key learning point: In the initial management of acute pancreatitis, especially when gallstones are suspected, aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation is crucial to prevent hypovolemia and maintain organ perfusion.

D) INCORRECT:

Immediate laparoscopic cholecystectomy is not appropriate in acute gallstone pancreatitis with hemodynamic instability. The patient requires aggressive fluid resuscitation and stabilization. Surgery is deferred until after the resolution of acute inflammation to reduce operative risks and complications. Elective cholecystectomy is performed later to prevent recurrent biliary events.

questions.text:
A 79-year-old man remains intubated in the ICU under sedation three days after an emergent laparotomy for a perforated sigmoid diverticulum. He has required prolonged vasopressor support for septic shock and has been receiving parenteral nutrition. Over the past 24 hours, he has persistent right upper quadrant abdominal distension. On examination, there is moderate tenderness in the right upper quadrant without rebound (see lab results and report).


Heart rate
110/min


Blood pressure
90/55 mm Hg while on vasopressors



Temperature
38.6°C




Test
Result
Normal Values



WBC
19 x 10⁹/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 10⁹/L


Total bilirubin
25 μmol/L
3.5 - 16.5 μmol/L



Abdominal ultrasound: Distended gallbladder with wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid, and no stones
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acalculous cholecystitis often occurs in critically ill patients due to factors like gallbladder ischemia and bile stasis, exacerbated by prolonged vasopressor use, parenteral nutrition, and sepsis. The ultrasound findings of a distended gallbladder with wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid, without gallstones, support this diagnosis. Percutaneous cholecystostomy provides a minimally invasive method to decompress the inflamed gallbladder, offering drainage to control infection and reduce inflammation. This approach is preferred in hemodynamically unstable patients, as it avoids the risks associated with surgery.

Key learning point: In critically ill patients with suspected acute acalculous cholecystitis, percutaneous cholecystostomy is often preferred as it is less invasive and can stabilize the patient by decompressing the gallbladder.

B) INCORRECT:

Cholescintigraphy, or HIDA scan, assesses gallbladder function but is unnecessary here due to clear ultrasound findings indicating acalculous cholecystitis. In critically ill patients, altered hepatic perfusion can reduce the reliability of cholescintigraphy, and the high pretest probability of acalculous cholecystitis makes further imaging redundant.

C) INCORRECT:

Immediate laparoscopic cholecystectomy is typically indicated for calculous cholecystitis in stable patients. However, this patient is critically ill and hemodynamically unstable due to septic shock, making surgery under general anesthesia high-risk. The ultrasound findings suggest acalculous cholecystitis, which is better managed with less invasive procedures in unstable patients.

D) INCORRECT:

While antibiotics are crucial in managing sepsis, the ultrasound findings of a distended gallbladder with wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid indicate a need for urgent source control. In acalculous cholecystitis, percutaneous drainage is necessary to address the infection's source, as antibiotics alone are insufficient.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department with 24 hours of right upper quadrant abdominal pain that worsens after meals, along with low-grade fevers and nausea. Examination reveals moderate tenderness in the right upper quadrant. Despite initial intravenous fluids and analgesia, he remains febrile (see lab result and report).

Temperature
38.3 °C



Test
Result
Normal Values


WBC
14.2 × 10⁹/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 10⁹/L


Right upper quadrant ultrasound: Gallbladder wall thickening of 5 mm, pericholecystic fluid, multiple gallstones, positive sonographic Murphy’s sign
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with stone retrieval

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute cholecystitis manifests with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and leukocytosis, often due to cystic duct obstruction by gallstones. Ultrasound findings such as gallbladder wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid, and a positive sonographic Murphy’s sign confirm the diagnosis. Early laparoscopic cholecystectomy is recommended to prevent complications like gangrene or perforation. This minimally invasive procedure offers benefits such as reduced postoperative pain and faster recovery compared to open cholecystectomy, making it the definitive treatment for patients who are surgical candidates.

Key learning point: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the standard treatment for acute cholecystitis, characterized by right upper quadrant pain, fever, leukocytosis, and ultrasound findings of gallbladder wall thickening and gallstones.

B) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is used for choledocholithiasis, where stones obstruct the common bile duct. The ultrasound findings indicate acute cholecystitis, not common bile duct obstruction, making ERCP inappropriate in this scenario.

C) INCORRECT:

Open cholecystectomy is reserved for cases where laparoscopic cholecystectomy is contraindicated, such as severe inflammation or complex anatomy. In uncomplicated acute cholecystitis, laparoscopic cholecystectomy is preferred due to its minimally invasive nature and quicker recovery.

D) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum antibiotics are adjunctive in managing acute cholecystitis to control infection but do not address the underlying gallstone obstruction. Without surgical intervention, the obstruction persists, leading to ongoing inflammation and potential complications. Antibiotics alone are insufficient for definitive management.

questions.text:
You are seeing a 42-year-old woman in the emergency department with a 2-day history of right upper abdominal pain and nausea. She is 163 cm tall and weighs 91 kg; her BMI is 34. Her temperature is 38.5°C. On examination, her abdomen is distended and there is right upper quadrant tenderness with normal bowel sounds. Laboratory studies show:


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
14.0 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)


Bilirubin, total, blood
19 μmol/L (3–17)


Aspartate aminotransferase (AST), blood
42 IU/L (15–37)


Alanine aminotransferase (ALT), blood
50 IU/L (17–63)


Alkaline phosphatase, blood
68 IU/L (50–136)


Abdominal ultrasonography is inconclusive. Cholescintigraphy (HIDA scan) shows normal visualization of the intrahepatic bile ducts, hepatic ducts, common bile duct, and proximal small bowel, but delayed visualization of the gallbladder. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?

choices.text: Fistula between the gallbladder and small intestine.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hypomotility of the gallbladder can result in biliary stasis, which predisposes to gallstone development and cholecystitis. This patient's acute symptoms, however, are likely caused by contraction of the gallbladder against an impacted stone rather than by decreased motility of the gallbladder.

B) INCORRECT:

A cholecystoenteric fistula (fistula between the gallbladder and small intestine) is often due to inflammation of the gallbladder wall. Fistulization provides a conduit for passage of gallstones, which may cause gallstone ileus. Patients with gallstone ileus can present with abdominal pain, nausea, and fever. However, physical examination would classically show high-pitched (tympanic) bowel sounds. In addition, even though cholescintigraphy is not a sensitive test for gallstone ileus, it would be expected to show communication between the gallbladder and intestinal tract rather than delayed uptake of radioactive tracer in the gallbladder. CT is the preferred imaging modality to confirm gallstone ileus and classically shows bowel obstruction with pneumobilia.

C) INCORRECT:

Infection with a hepatotropic virus (e.g., hepatitis A) can cause acute hepatitis. While acute hepatitis can manifest with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and fever, it usually also manifests with markedly elevated liver function tests (e.g., AST, ALT), which are only mildly elevated in this patient. Moreover, a cholescintigraphy showing delayed uptake of radioactive tracer in the gallbladder suggests another etiology.

D) CORRECT:

Cholecystitis is usually caused by the passage of gallstones into the cystic duct. Cystic duct obstruction can lead to gallbladder inflammation with symptoms of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and fever, as seen in this patient. Cholescintigraphy (HIDA scan) typically shows delayed or absent uptake of radioactive tracer in the gallbladder; a HIDA scan is primarily used to diagnose cystic duct obstruction if RUQ ultrasound fails to show gallstones. In uncomplicated cholecystitis, cholestasis parameters (i.e., ALP, GGT, and bilirubin) are typically normal or only mildly elevated because there is usually no obstruction of the hepatic ducts or common bile duct.

Key learning point: Obstruction of the cystic duct, often by gallstones, leads to acute cholecystitis and is indicated by delayed gallbladder visualization on a HIDA scan.
Image Description:

The right and left hepatic ducts join to form the common hepatic duct. The cystic duct joins the common hepatic duct to form the common bile duct. The main pancreatic duct drains into the common bile duct. The common bile duct opens into the descending part of the duodenum.

E) INCORRECT:

Autodigestion of pancreatic parenchyma due to a local release of digestive proteolytic enzymes is seen in pancreatitis. While pancreatitis can manifest with abdominal pain, nausea, and fever, the abdominal pain in pancreatitis is typically epigastric (not right upper abdominal pain) and radiates towards the back. Moreover, cholescintigraphy showing delayed uptake of radioactive tracer in the gallbladder suggests another etiology.
questions.hint: This patient has risk factors for gallstone disease (e.g., obesity, age > 40, female). Right upper quadrant pain, nausea, fever, and leukocytosis suggest acute cholecystitis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to your clinic with intermittent abdominal pain for the past month. She describes the pain as being in the right upper abdomen and notes that it does not change with food intake. She denies nausea, vomiting, or weight change. Her medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She does not smoke and drinks 1–2 glasses of wine daily. Her current medications are captopril and atorvastatin. On examination, you find a small, firm mass in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory studies are within the reference range. A CT scan of the abdomen is provided. This condition puts her at greatest risk of developing which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient does not exhibit any of the common risk factors for the development of a pyogenic liver abscess, such as biliary obstruction, gastrointestinal illness, bacteremia, or pancreatitis. Porcelain gallbladder is not a risk factor for pyogenic liver abscess.

B) INCORRECT:

Both porcelain gallbladder and gallbladder perforation are complications of cholelithiasis and cholecystitis. Porcelain gallbladder itself is not a common cause of gallbladder perforation.

C) CORRECT:

While the exact pathophysiology of porcelain gallbladder is unknown, it is associated with cholelithiasis and chronic gallbladder inflammation. Porcelain gallbladder is often identified incidentally on abdominal imaging, although it may manifest with right upper quadrant pain, as seen in this patient. Porcelain gallbladder is associated with a small but significant risk of developing gallbladder adenocarcinoma. Management can either be conservative or involve laparoscopic cholecystectomy (e.g., in symptomatic patients).

Key learning point: Porcelain gallbladder, characterized by calcification of the gallbladder wall, is associated with an increased risk of developing gallbladder adenocarcinoma.
Image Description:

X-ray abdomen (AP view)

A well-defined oval lesion is visible in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, encapsulated in a thin rim of radiodense material, indicating intramural calcification of the gallbladder.

This is the typical appearance of porcelain gallbladder, which is a consequence of chronic gallbladder inflammation that is usually secondary to cholelithiasis.

D) INCORRECT:

The two greatest risk factors for pancreatic cancer are smoking and chronic pancreatitis. CT is generally the initial imaging modality used for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis, and classic findings include pancreatic atrophy, ductal dilatation, calcification, and/or pseudocyst formation, none of which is seen here. Porcelain gallbladder is not a risk factor for pancreatic adenocarcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

The two greatest risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma are liver cirrhosis and chronic viral hepatitis. This patient does not have any history to suggest underlying chronic viral hepatitis (e.g., jaundice, hepatomegaly, history of IV drug use) and she does not show stigmata of cirrhosis (e.g., abdominal distention, ascites, spider angiomas, peripheral edema). Porcelain gallbladder is not a risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma.
questions.hint: This patient's abdominal CT scan shows an opaque lesion in the right upper quadrant suggestive of gallbladder calcification. This is also referred to as porcelain gallbladder.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with right upper abdominal pain, fever, and nausea that have progressively worsened since eating a large meal 8 hours ago. On examination, her abdomen is soft with normal bowel sounds. She has sudden inspiratory arrest during palpation of the right upper quadrant. Laboratory studies reveal leukocytosis. Serum concentrations of alkaline phosphatase, total bilirubin, amylase, and aspartate aminotransferase are within reference ranges. Imaging is most likely to show which one of the following findings?

choices.text: Enlargement of the pancreas with peripancreatic fluid.
Dilated common bile duct with intrahepatic biliary dilatation.
Fistula formation between the gallbladder and bowel.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gas within the gallbladder wall, also referred to as emphysematous cholecystitis, suggests either gallbladder necrosis or infection with gas-forming bacteria. It is typically a complication of untreated cholecystitis (including acalculous cholecystitis) and can be visualized on both ultrasound and CT. However, this patient is not critically ill and her abdominal pain is acute, making this an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Edema of the pancreas on either ultrasound or CT suggests acute pancreatitis. Patients with pancreatitis often present with abdominal pain and nausea that may be worse after meals. However, pain from pancreatitis is classically located in the epigastric area and radiates to the back, and it is not associated with the Murphy sign. Elevations in serum amylase and lipase would also be expected in acute pancreatitis.

C) CORRECT:

The vast majority of cases of acute cholecystitis are due to obstructing gallstones in the cystic duct. In a patient with clinical features of acute cholecystitis (e.g., RUQ pain lasting over 6 hours, fever, and leukocytosis), ultrasonography of the RUQ is indicated. Findings that support the diagnosis include gallbladder wall thickening, gallbladder wall edema, obstructing gallstone, and/or sonographic Murphy sign. Gallstones are a common incidental finding on ultrasound but in this context would also be suggestive of acute cholecystitis. In uncomplicated cholecystitis, cholestasis parameters (ALP, GGT, and bilirubin) are typically normal or only mildly elevated because there is usually no obstruction of the hepatic ducts or common bile duct.

Key learning point: Acute cholecystitis is most often caused by a gallstone obstructing the cystic duct, with imaging typically showing the obstructing stone and gallbladder wall thickening.
Image Description:

Ultrasound gallbladder

The gallbladder is dilated and its wall (green overlay) is thickened and striated (alternate hyperechoic and hypoechoic layers) as a result of edema. A calculus within dependent sludge in the neck produces posterior acoustic shadowing (red overlay) and has a highly reflective echogenic anterior surface (green hatched overlay).

Ultrasound findings in acute cholecystitis include wall thickening, dilatation, pericholecystic fluid, and a positive sonographic Murphy sign. The presence of multiple ultrasound findings increases diagnostic accuracy for cholecystitis.

L: liver

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of a dilated common bile duct and intrahepatic biliary dilatation on ultrasound suggests choledocholithiasis. Choledocholithiasis typically presents with RUQ pain, nausea, and occasionally jaundice. Elevation in serum ALP and bilirubin is common. Fever and leukocytosis would be unusual and are typically only seen in patients with complications of choledocholithiasis, such as acute pancreatitis or acute cholangitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Gallstone ileus is a very rare complication of gallstone cholecystitis and occurs when a biliary enteric fistula is formed that leads to a gallstone entering the small intestine and obstructing the ileum. Patients can present with symptoms of small bowel obstruction, including nausea, vomiting (often bilious), crampy abdominal pain, and obstipation. Physical examination would show abdominal distention and high-pitched (tympanic) bowel sounds. CT is the preferred imaging modality and classically shows bowel obstruction with a biliary enteric fistula and/or pneumobilia.
questions.hint: This patient presents with postprandial RUQ pain, fever, leukocytosis, and a positive Murphy sign, suggesting a diagnosis of acute cholecystitis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with nausea and severe abdominal pain. She reports that the pain worsens after meals and can last the entire day. On examination, there is tenderness in the right upper quadrant on abdominal palpation. The remainder of the physical examination is normal. Laboratory studies reveal leukocytosis and mildly elevated alkaline phosphatase, AST, and ALT. Right upper quadrant ultrasonography is inconclusive. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging of the abdomen.
Computed tomography scan of the abdomen.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is indicated in patients with choledocholithiasis, which can manifest similarly to this patient's clinical presentation. ERCP is the preferred imaging study to diagnose choledocholithiasis and is also therapeutic. However, choledocholithiasis classically causes increased concentrations of bilirubin and gamma-glutamyltransferase, neither of which is seen in this patient. Because this patient has suspected uncomplicated acute cholecystitis rather than choledocholithiasis, an alternative study is indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

A magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is used in the diagnosis of choledocholithiasis, which can manifest similarly to this patient's clinical presentation. However, choledocholithiasis classically causes increased serum concentrations of bilirubin and gamma-glutamyltransferase, neither of which are seen here. Because this patient has suspected uncomplicated acute cholecystitis rather than choledocholithiasis, an alternative study is indicated.

C) CORRECT:

Cholescintigraphy, also called hepatoiminodiacetic acid scintigraphy (HIDA scan), is the preferred imaging study in patients with both suspected uncomplicated acute cholecystitis and inconclusive findings on abdominal ultrasound, such as this woman. Technetium-99m, a tracer that is selectively secreted into the biliary tree, is injected intravenously and allows for visualization of the biliary tract. An obstructing gallstone and/or inflammatory edema impairs the filling of the gallbladder. The diagnosis is confirmed if the gallbladder cannot be visualized on imaging (i.e., lack of gallbladder filling) within 4 hours.

Key learning point: When right upper quadrant ultrasound is inconclusive for acute cholecystitis, cholescintigraphy (HIDA scan) is the next best diagnostic test.

D) INCORRECT:

MRI is an alternative imaging modality used to diagnose acute cholecystitis in patients who have inconclusive ultrasound results. MRI is especially useful for those who have a contraindication to CT scan (e.g., pregnancy, contrast allergy). However, another alternative study for diagnosing uncomplicated acute cholecystitis is indicated prior to MRI.

E) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the abdomen is an alternative imaging modality used to diagnose acute cholecystitis in patients who have inconclusive ultrasound results. CT scan is also used to evaluate possible complications of cholecystitis, such as hemorrhage, emphysematous cholecystitis, gallstone ileus, and gangrenous cholecystitis. However, another alternative study for diagnosing uncomplicated acute cholecystitis is indicated prior to CT.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical presentation (long-lasting postprandial abdominal pain, nausea, RUQ tenderness) in combination with her laboratory findings (leukocytosis, mildly elevated ALP, AST, and ALT) suggests acute cholecystitis. Since abdominal ultrasound findings were inconclusive, a different test is needed to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: Three days after coronary artery bypass surgery, a 72-year-old man in your care develops severe right upper quadrant pain, fever, nausea, and vomiting. His medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, benign prostatic hyperplasia, peripheral vascular disease, and chronic mesenteric ischemia. On abdominal examination, his abdomen is soft with tenderness and sudden inspiratory arrest on palpation in the right upper quadrant. There is no rebound tenderness or guarding. Laboratory studies reveal leukocytosis. Abdominal ultrasonography shows a distended gallbladder, thickened gallbladder wall with pericholecystic fluid, and no stones. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Intravenous heparin therapy followed by embolectomy.
Careful observation with serial abdominal examinations.
Intravenous piperacillin-tazobactam therapy and percutaneous cholecystostomy.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous heparin therapy followed by embolectomy can be performed to treat embolic diseases such as acute mesenteric ischemia, which manifests with abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting as seen in this patient. However, acute mesenteric ischemia would not explain this patient's findings on abdominal ultrasound, which are more consistent with acalculous cholecystitis and warrant a different treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Observation with serial examinations may be appropriate for diseases that have the potential to resolve on their own without complications. This patient with acalculous cholecystitis is at high risk of gallbladder perforation and rapid deterioration. He should receive appropriate treatment as soon as possible.

C) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography with papillotomy and placement of a stent between the gallbladder and the duodenum to decompress the gallbladder can be performed as a palliative treatment in patients with acalculous cholecystitis who are high-risk surgical candidates. However, in this patient, curative treatment is indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Cholecystectomy is the definitive treatment of acalculous cholecystitis. However, in severely ill patients such as this one, another less invasive procedure should first be conducted. If the patient does not improve within 24 hours after initial treatment, cholecystectomy should be performed.

E) CORRECT:

Acalculous cholecystitis puts this patient at high risk of gallbladder perforation and rapid deterioration. Apart from fluid resuscitation, he should be started on broad-spectrum antibiotics such as piperacillin-tazobactam immediately, and cholecystostomy should be performed to decompress his distended gallbladder. Cholecystectomy is the definitive treatment for acalculous cholecystitis. A percutaneous cholecystostomy, on the other hand, is a less invasive temporizing alternative for severely ill patients (such as this patient, who has several severe diseases and has recently undergone a major surgical procedure) or patients too unstable to be under general anesthesia. If the patient does not improve within 24 hours, a cholecystectomy should be performed.

Key learning point: Acute acalculous cholecystitis in critically ill patients requires prompt broad-spectrum antibiotics and percutaneous cholecystostomy for gallbladder decompression, as definitive surgery is often deferred until the patient stabilizes.
questions.hint: This patient's fever, right upper quadrant pain, positive Murphy sign, and ultrasound findings of a distended gallbladder with thickened wall and pericholecystic fluid are consistent with acute cholecystitis. Considering that he has several illnesses, has recently undergone a major surgical procedure, and that there is no evidence of stones in the gallbladder, he likely has acute acalculous cholecystitis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease presents with a 12-hour history of epigastric pain that has migrated to the right upper quadrant. She reports nausea and decreased appetite but denies fever or chills. Vital signs are BP, 140/90; P, 95; R, 14; T, 37.7°C (99.9°F). Physical examination shows right upper quadrant tenderness with a positive Murphy sign. Laboratory studies show WBC 11,500/μL, creatinine 1.8 mg/dL, AST 45 U/L, ALT 52 U/L, total bilirubin 1.2 mg/dL, and alkaline phosphatase 110 U/L. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order CT abdomen with IV contrast
Initiate empiric antibiotics and consult surgery for urgent laparoscopic cholecystectomy
Obtain magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography to evaluate for choledocholithiasis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cholescintigraphy (also known as a HIDA scan) is an imaging study reserved for when ultrasound findings are inconclusive. This modality is time-consuming and should not be used as the initial imaging modality when ultrasound is readily available.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – Right upper quadrant ultrasound is the preferred initial imaging modality for suspected acute cholecystitis. This patient presents with characteristic clinical features including right upper quadrant pain, a positive Murphy sign, and laboratory findings consistent with inflammation. Characteristic findings on ultrasound include gallbladder wall thickening, distention, pericholecystic fluid, and gallstones.

C) INCORRECT:

CT abdomen with IV contrast is not the preferred initial imaging modality for suspected acute cholecystitis. Additionally, IV contrast can be potentially nephrotoxic for patients with chronic kidney disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic therapy and surgical consult are appropriate for confirmed acute cholecystitis, but the diagnosis must first be confirmed via imaging.

E) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography is used to evaluate for choledocholithiasis in patients with suspected bile duct obstruction. This patient's laboratory values show only a mild elevation of liver enzymes without significant cholestasis, making choledocholithiasis unlikely.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with a history of bariatric surgery six months ago presents with 8 hours of severe, constant right upper quadrant pain radiating to her right scapula that began after a fatty meal. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F) and her pulse is 110/min. Physical examination reveals marked tenderness and guarding in the right upper quadrant. Upon deep palpation of the right upper quadrant, the patient pauses during inspiration. Laboratory studies show a white blood cell count of 14,500/mm3. Abdominal ultrasonography is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: A hyperechoic stone within a dilated common bile duct
Multiple mobile stones in the gallbladder without wall changes
Gallbladder wall thickening >3 mm and pericholecystic fluid
Circumferential calcification of the gallbladder wall

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This finding describes choledocholithiasis, which is a gallstone in the common bile duct. While it can cause right upper quadrant pain and is part of the differential diagnosis, the patient's positive Murphy sign points specifically to gallbladder inflammation rather than just biliary obstruction. A dilated common bile duct is the key finding for choledocholithiasis, not acute cholecystitis.

B) INCORRECT:

These ultrasound findings are nonspecific and suggest underlying liver parenchymal disease, such as cirrhosis or steatohepatitis. While liver pathology can cause right upper quadrant pain, these findings do not explain the acute, focal signs of gallbladder inflammation, such as the positive Murphy sign.

C) INCORRECT:

This describes cholelithiasis, the presence of gallstones. Although gallstones are the underlying cause of this patient's condition, this finding by itself does not indicate acute inflammation. This patient's findings suggest acute cholecystitis, which is accompanied by inflammatory changes on ultrasound.

D) CORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasonography is the preferred initial imaging modality in suspected acute cholecystitis. The sonographic hallmarks of acute cholecystitis are signs of gallbladder inflammation, including gallbladder wall thickening (>3 mm), pericholecystic fluid, and a sonographic Murphy sign.

The patient's history of bariatric surgery is a significant risk factor for acute cholecystitis, as rapid weight loss promotes gallstone formation (cholelithiasis).

E) INCORRECT:

This describes a porcelain gallbladder, a manifestation of chronic cholecystitis. It is a rare condition associated with an increased risk of gallbladder carcinoma. This finding is related to long-standing inflammation and fibrosis, not the acute inflammatory process in acute cholecystitis.
questions.hint: The patient's clinical features are suggestive of acute cholecystitis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 12-hour history of severe, constant right upper quadrant pain that radiates to her right scapula. The pain began after a fatty meal and is associated with nausea and subjective fever. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), blood pressure is 145/88 mmHg, and pulse is 105/min. Physical examination reveals marked tenderness in the right upper quadrant with inspiratory arrest on palpation. Laboratory studies show a white blood cell count of 13,000/mm3 with a normal total bilirubin. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial diagnostic study?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is an invasive procedure that is both diagnostic and therapeutic, primarily for conditions of the common bile duct, such as choledocholithiasis or ascending cholangitis. Given the patient's normal total bilirubin, obstruction of the common bile duct is unlikely. ERCP carries significant risks, including pancreatitis and perforation, and is not indicated as a primary diagnostic tool for uncomplicated acute cholecystitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is a non-invasive imaging technique that provides detailed visualization of the entire biliary tree and is excellent for detecting common bile duct stones. However, it is more time-consuming and less readily available than ultrasound. It is not the appropriate initial test for suspected acute cholecystitis, especially when the normal bilirubin level makes common bile duct pathology less likely. Its use is typically reserved for when choledocholithiasis is suspected.

C) INCORRECT:

A hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan, or cholescintigraphy, is the most accurate test for acute cholecystitis. It assesses gallbladder function by tracking a radiotracer from the liver to the small intestine. However, it is not the initial test. It is reserved for cases where the clinical suspicion is high but the initial ultrasound is inconclusive or equivocal. Non-visualization of the gallbladder on a HIDA scan indicates cystic duct obstruction, confirming the diagnosis.

D) CORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasonography is the initial imaging test of choice for suspected acute cholecystitis. It is readily available, non-invasive, and does not involve ionizing radiation. Ultrasonography is highly sensitive and specific for detecting gallstones, the most common cause of cystic duct obstruction leading to cholecystitis. Key diagnostic findings include gallbladder wall thickening (greater than 3-4 mm), pericholecystic fluid, and a sonographic Murphy's sign (focal tenderness over the gallbladder with the ultrasound probe). The combination of these findings confirms the diagnosis in the appropriate clinical setting.

E) INCORRECT:

An abdominal CT scan can identify gallbladder inflammation, wall thickening, and pericholecystic fluid. However, it is less sensitive than ultrasound for detecting gallstones, which are the underlying cause in most cases. A CT scan is typically reserved for evaluating for complications of cholecystitis, such as perforation or abscess formation, or when alternative diagnoses like pancreatitis or appendicitis are being considered in a patient with undifferentiated abdominal pain.
questions.hint: This patient's right upper quadrant pain, fever, leukocytosis, and positive Murphy's sign strongly suggest a diagnosis of acute cholecystitis, which is typically caused by a gallstone obstructing the cystic duct.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of 12 hours of severe, constant right-sided abdominal pain that radiates to her right shoulder. The pain began after a large meal. She also reports nausea and fever. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia. Her temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows marked tenderness in the right upper quadrant with inspiratory arrest on deep palpation. Laboratory studies show a white blood cell count of 14,500/mm3. An ultrasound is ordered. Which of the following ultrasound findings would be expected in this patient?

choices.text: Gallbladder wall thickening and pericholecystic free fluid
Hyperechoic sludge completely filling the gallbladder lumen
A complex, rim-enhancing fluid collection within the hepatic parenchyma
Multiple mobile echogenic foci with posterior acoustic shadowing

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acute cholecystitis typically leads to bile stasis, increased intraluminal pressure, and inflammation of the gallbladder wall. On ultrasound, these inflammatory changes manifest as gallbladder wall thickening (typically > 3 mm) and pericholecystic free fluid, which is fluid accumulation around the gallbladder. These findings, along with a sonographic Murphy's sign (maximal tenderness over the sonographically localized gallbladder), are the most specific signs for acute cholecystitis. While gallstones are usually present, it is the evidence of inflammation that confirms the diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Biliary sludge is a mixture of particulate solids that have precipitated from bile. While it can be associated with biliary stasis and can cause acalculous cholecystitis, the presence of sludge alone cannot confirm the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis. Furthermore, biliary sludge can be an incidental finding in patients who are fasting, pregnant, or critically ill.

C) INCORRECT:

This finding is characteristic of a pyogenic liver abscess, an infection within the liver tissue itself. While a perforated gallbladder can be a rare cause of a liver abscess, this description is not a primary finding of acute cholecystitis. The patient's signs and symptoms are more directly explained by gallbladder inflammation.

D) INCORRECT:

Multiple mobile echogenic foci with posterior acoustic shadowing describe the typical ultrasound features of cholelithiasis. While approximately 90% of acute cholecystitis cases are caused by gallstones, this finding alone is not diagnostic of inflammation. Many individuals have asymptomatic cholelithiasis. The presence of gallstones is a prerequisite for calculous cholecystitis, but does not confirm it.
questions.hint: This patient's signs and symptoms, including fever, leukocytosis, a positive Murphy's sign, and right upper quadrant pain, are suggestive of acute cholecystitis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of severe right-sided abdominal pain, fever, and nausea. He has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and peripheral vascular disease. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 98/68 mm Hg. He appears ill. Physical examination reveals marked tenderness and guarding in the right upper quadrant and a positive Murphy sign. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 18,000/mm3 with a left shift and a total bilirubin of 2.5 mg/dL. An abdominal CT scan demonstrates gallbladder wall thickening, pericholecystic fluid, and air within the gallbladder wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A perforated peptic ulcer is a surgical emergency and can manifest with severe upper abdominal pain, fever, and signs of peritonitis. However, the pain is typically epigastric, and the positive Murphy sign strongly localizes the pathology to the gallbladder. Furthermore, imaging in a perforated ulcer would be expected to show free intraperitoneal air (pneumoperitoneum), not air confined within the gallbladder wall.

B) INCORRECT:

Ascending cholangitis might be considered because the patient presents with fever, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice (elevated bilirubin), which constitute Charcot's triad. However, the CT findings point specifically to pathology within the gallbladder itself. Ascending cholangitis is an infection of the biliary tree, which would typically be associated with common bile duct dilation on imaging, a finding not described here.

C) INCORRECT:

Gallstone pancreatitis is a consideration in patients with biliary colic symptoms. While the patient has right upper quadrant pain and nausea, the clinical picture is more localized to the gallbladder, with a positive Murphy sign being a key feature. A diagnosis of pancreatitis typically requires elevated lipase or amylase and characteristic imaging findings related to the pancreas, none of which are present.

D) CORRECT:

Emphysematous cholecystitis is a rare, life-threatening form of acute cholecystitis caused by infection with gas-forming organisms such as Clostridium perfringens or Escherichia coli. It is characterized by the presence of air within the gallbladder wall or lumen, a pathognomonic finding seen on imaging. Key risk factors include advanced age, male sex, diabetes mellitus, and peripheral vascular disease, which compromise blood flow to the gallbladder and impair immune response. Patients often present more acutely ill than those with typical cholecystitis, with high fever and signs of sepsis. Due to a high risk of gangrene and perforation, this condition requires emergent surgical intervention (cholecystectomy) and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
questions.hint: The pathognomonic imaging sign for this condition is air within the gallbladder wall or lumen.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man, who is 8 days post-coronary artery bypass grafting, develops a fever and right upper quadrant abdominal pain. His hospital course has been complicated by prolonged ileus requiring total parenteral nutrition. He is currently mechanically ventilated. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), heart rate is 115/min, and blood pressure is 95/60 mmHg. Physical examination reveals tenderness and guarding in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory studies show a WBC count of 18,500/mm3, total bilirubin of 3.2 mg/dL, and an alkaline phosphatase of 450 U/L. An abdominal ultrasound demonstrates a distended gallbladder with a thickened wall and pericholecystic fluid, but no gallstones. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial intervention?

choices.text: Initiation of broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics alone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid (HIDA) scan is a functional study of the gallbladder that can confirm a diagnosis of acute cholecystitis by demonstrating non-visualization of the gallbladder, indicating cystic duct obstruction. However, this patient is critically ill and requires urgent therapeutic intervention, not further diagnostic confirmation. The clinical picture and ultrasound findings are sufficient to proceed with treatment, and delaying care for a HIDA scan would be inappropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

While cholecystectomy is the definitive treatment for acute cholecystitis, this patient is hemodynamically unstable, mechanically ventilated, and only eight days post-major cardiac surgery. Proceeding with an emergent major abdominal surgery carries an extremely high risk of morbidity and mortality in this context.

C) CORRECT:

Major surgery, total parenteral nutrition, and ileus are significant risk factors for acute acalculous cholecystitis. This patient is hemodynamically unstable and septic, making him a very poor candidate for general anesthesia and surgery. The most appropriate initial intervention is percutaneous cholecystostomy, an image-guided procedure to place a drainage tube into the gallbladder. This provides immediate source control by decompressing the gallbladder and draining purulent material, which is crucial in managing sepsis. It serves as a bridge, stabilizing the patient for a potential future cholecystectomy when he is a better surgical candidate.

D) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics are a critical component of managing acute acalculous cholecystitis and sepsis. However, they are insufficient as a standalone therapy. This condition represents a closed-space infection with gallbladder distention, ischemia, and risk of gangrene or perforation. A different management approach is required in addition to antibiotics to resolve the infection and prevent complications.

E) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure primarily used to evaluate and treat conditions of the common bile duct and pancreatic duct, such as choledocholithiasis or ascending cholangitis. This patient's ultrasound shows pathology confined to the gallbladder itself, with no mention of biliary ductal dilation.
questions.hint: This critically ill, postoperative patient has clinical and sonographic evidence of acute acalculous cholecystitis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department with 6 hours of severe, constant right upper quadrant pain that began after eating a large meal. The pain radiates to his right shoulder. He has also experienced nausea and two episodes of nonbloody emesis. He has type 2 diabetes and hyperlipidemia. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. On examination, there is marked tenderness in the right upper quadrant with inspiratory arrest during palpation. Laboratory studies show a WBC count of 14,500/mm³. An abdominal ultrasound is performed. Which of the following findings is most specific for the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: Sludge within the gallbladder lumen without stones
Multiple echogenic foci with posterior acoustic shadowing
Dilation of the common bile duct to 9 mm
Pericholecystic fluid and gallbladder wall thickening
Hypoechoic, wedge-shaped area in the right hepatic lobe

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Biliary sludge is a mixture of calcium bilirubinate granules and cholesterol crystals. While it can cause biliary colic and acalculous cholecystitis, its presence alone is a nonspecific finding. Sludge can be seen incidentally in patients who are fasting, pregnant, or receiving total parenteral nutrition, and it does not confirm active inflammation without other sonographic signs.

B) INCORRECT:

This finding describes cholelithiasis (gallstones). While over 90% of acute cholecystitis cases are caused by an impacted gallstone, the presence of stones alone is not specific for acute inflammation. Many individuals have asymptomatic gallstones. Therefore, this finding indicates the prerequisite for calculous cholecystitis but does not confirm the diagnosis of active inflammation.

C) INCORRECT:

A dilated common bile duct (normal is <6 mm) suggests obstruction distal to the gallbladder, most commonly from choledocholithiasis (a stone in the common bile duct). This finding is more specific for choledocholithiasis or ascending cholangitis than for acute cholecystitis, which is typically caused by obstruction of the cystic duct.

D) CORRECT:

The clinical presentation is classic for acute cholecystitis. While cholelithiasis is the most common cause, the diagnosis requires evidence of gallbladder inflammation. On ultrasound, the most specific findings are direct signs of this inflammation. These include gallbladder wall thickening (typically >3 mm), edema within the wall, and pericholecystic fluid. A sonographic Murphy sign (maximal tenderness elicited by the ultrasound probe over the gallbladder) is also highly specific. These findings directly visualize the inflammatory process, distinguishing acute cholecystitis from uncomplicated biliary colic or asymptomatic cholelithiasis. A hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid scan is the most sensitive test if ultrasound is equivocal.

E) INCORRECT:

This sonographic description is characteristic of a focal hepatic lesion, such as a liver abscess or infarct. Although a liver abscess can manifest with fever and right upper quadrant pain, this patient's classic postprandial pain onset and positive Murphy sign specifically indicate that the gallbladder, not the liver parenchyma, is the source of pathology.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with 12 hours of severe, constant right upper quadrant pain that radiates to her right shoulder. The pain began after eating a large, fatty meal and is associated with nausea and two episodes of non-bloody emesis. She has a history of type 2 diabetes. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows marked tenderness in the right upper quadrant with inspiratory arrest on palpation. Laboratory studies show a white blood cell count of 14,500/mm³. An abdominal ultrasound shows a thickened gallbladder wall, pericholecystic fluid, and gallstones. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ursodeoxycholic acid is a bile acid used to dissolve cholesterol gallstones over a long period. It is an option for patients with symptomatic cholelithiasis (biliary colic) who are not surgical candidates. It has no role in the management of acute cholecystitis, which is an acute inflammatory and infectious process requiring immediate intervention, not long-term dissolution therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous cholecystostomy is a procedure to drain an infected gallbladder. It is a valid treatment for acute cholecystitis but is reserved for patients who are critically ill or are otherwise poor surgical candidates and cannot tolerate general anesthesia for a cholecystectomy. This patient is hemodynamically stable and does not have contraindications to surgery described, making this intervention inappropriate as a first step.

C) INCORRECT:

Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the definitive treatment for acute cholecystitis. However, current guidelines recommend early cholecystectomy, typically within 72 hours of presentation, as it is associated with shorter hospital stays and fewer complications. An interval cholecystectomy after several weeks is generally reserved for patients who present late (more than 72 hours after symptom onset) or in whom initial medical management fails and a percutaneous drain is placed.

D) CORRECT:

The initial management of this patient with acute cholecystitis focuses on medical stabilization, which includes placing the patient on a nothing-by-mouth status to reduce gallbladder stimulation, providing intravenous fluids for hydration, administering analgesics for pain control, and starting intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics. The antibiotics should cover common enteric organisms like Escherichia coli and Klebsiella. This approach aims to control the infection and inflammation, reduce the risk of complications like sepsis or gallbladder perforation, and prepare the patient for definitive treatment, which is typically an early laparoscopic cholecystectomy within 24–72 hours.

E) INCORRECT:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is indicated for diagnosing and treating conditions of the common bile duct, such as choledocholithiasis or ascending cholangitis. This patient's signs, symptoms, and ultrasound findings are localized to the gallbladder, with no evidence of biliary obstruction like jaundice or a dilated common bile duct. Therefore, ERCP is not indicated and carries unnecessary risks.
questions.hint: This patient's clinical presentation and ultrasound findings are classic for acute cholecystitis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 12-hour history of severe, constant right upper quadrant pain that radiates to her right shoulder. The pain began after she ate a large, fatty meal. She reports associated nausea and subjective fever. Her medical history is significant for obesity and hyperlipidemia. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), her pulse is 105/min, and her blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. On examination, there is marked tenderness in the right upper quadrant with inspiratory arrest during palpation. Laboratory studies show a WBC count of 13,500/mm³. Ultrasonography of the abdomen is performed. Which of the following findings is most indicative of the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: Multiple mobile echogenic foci with acoustic shadowing
Gallbladder wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid
Dilation of the common bile duct to 9 mm

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This describes cholelithiasis, or the presence of gallstones. Although more than 90% of acute cholecystitis cases are caused by gallstones (calculous cholecystitis), the presence of stones alone does not confirm inflammation. Many individuals have asymptomatic cholelithiasis. The diagnosis of acute cholecystitis requires evidence of gallbladder inflammation in addition to the presence of stones.

B) CORRECT:

The clinical presentation is classic for acute cholecystitis. The diagnosis is confirmed with imaging, and ultrasound is the initial test of choice. The most specific sonographic findings for acute cholecystitis are direct signs of inflammation. These include gallbladder wall thickening (typically >3 mm), pericholecystic fluid, and a sonographic Murphy sign (maximal tenderness over the sonographically identified gallbladder). These findings are caused by gallbladder wall edema and inflammation resulting from cystic duct obstruction, most commonly by a gallstone. Although gallstones are usually present, the signs of inflammation confirm the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Dilation of the common bile duct (typically >6 mm) suggests choledocholithiasis or another cause of distal biliary obstruction. While this can occur in conjunction with acute cholecystitis, it is not a primary diagnostic feature of the condition. This patient's signs and symptoms are localized to the gallbladder, making inflammation of the gallbladder itself the primary concern.

D) INCORRECT:

This describes a porcelain gallbladder, a rare condition characterized by intramural calcification of the gallbladder wall. It is a chronic finding, not a sign of acute inflammation. A porcelain gallbladder is clinically significant because it is associated with an increased risk of gallbladder carcinoma, but it does not cause the acute inflammatory symptoms seen in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of fever, leukocytosis, and a positive Murphy sign points to an inflammatory process of the gallbladder, not just the presence of stones.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department with a 36-hour history of right upper quadrant pain, intermittent nausea, and low-grade fever. She has no significant comorbidities. Physical examination shows localized right upper quadrant tenderness with a positive Murphy sign (see lab result and report).

Heart rate
100/min



Test
Result
Normal Values


WBC
14 x 10⁹/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 10⁹/L


Abdominal ultrasound: Gallstones and gallbladder wall thickening without signs of abscess or perforation
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Intravenous antibiotics until serial imaging confirms resolution

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Interval cholecystectomy is considered when immediate surgery poses high risk or diagnosis is uncertain. This patient, with a short duration of symptoms and clear signs of acute cholecystitis, is a candidate for early surgery. Delaying surgery may allow inflammation to progress, increasing the risk of complications and making the procedure more difficult due to adhesions.

B) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous cholecystostomy is reserved for patients with acute cholecystitis who are poor surgical candidates due to severe comorbidities or hemodynamic instability. It is a temporizing measure when surgery is contraindicated. This patient, with no significant comorbidities and stable vital signs, is an appropriate candidate for early laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

C) CORRECT:

Acute cholecystitis manifests with right upper quadrant pain, a positive Murphy sign, and leukocytosis, often due to gallstone obstruction of the cystic duct. Ultrasound findings of gallstones and gallbladder wall thickening confirm the diagnosis. Early laparoscopic cholecystectomy is recommended for stable patients with minimal comorbidities, as it removes the source of inflammation, reduces the risk of complications, and minimizes recurrence. Performing the procedure within 72 hours of symptom onset is ideal, as it leverages clearer tissue planes before extensive inflammation develops, facilitating a successful minimally invasive surgery.

Key learning point: In cases of mild acute cholecystitis, early laparoscopic cholecystectomy within 72 hours is recommended to reduce hospital stay and complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous antibiotics are important in managing acute cholecystitis, especially in patients who are poor surgical candidates. However, they are not definitive therapy for otherwise healthy patients. Current guidelines recommend early surgical intervention, such as laparoscopic cholecystectomy, to address the underlying gallstone obstruction and prevent recurrence. Serial imaging is not standard for assessing resolution; clinical improvement and laboratory findings are the primary metrics.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of right upper abdominal pain and nausea. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 91 kg (200 lb); her BMI is 34 kg/m2. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Physical examination shows a distended abdomen and right upper quadrant tenderness with normal bowel sounds. Laboratory studies show:


Leukocyte count
14,000/mm3


Serum



Total bilirubin
1.1 mg/dL


AST
42 U/L


ALT
50 U/L


Alkaline phosphatase
68 U/L


Abdominal ultrasonography is performed, but the results are inconclusive. Cholescintigraphy (HIDA scan) shows normal visualization of the intrahepatic bile ducts, hepatic ducts, common bile duct, and proximal small bowel; visualization of the gallbladder is delayed. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Fistula between the gallbladder and small intestine
Fibrosis of the common bile duct

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Autodigestion of pancreatic parenchyma due to a local release of digestive proteolytic enzymes is seen in pancreatitis. While pancreatitis can manifest with abdominal pain, nausea, and fever, the abdominal pain in pancreatitis is typically epigastric (not right upper abdominal pain) and radiates towards the back. Moreover, cholescintigraphy showing delayed uptake of radioactive tracer in the gallbladder suggests another etiology.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypomotility of the gallbladder can result in biliary stasis, which predisposes to gallstone development and cholecystitis. This patient's acute symptoms, however, are likely caused by contraction of the gallbladder against an impacted stone rather than by decreased motility of the gallbladder.

C) INCORRECT:

A cholecystoenteric fistula (fistula between the gallbladder and small intestine) is often due to inflammation of the gallbladder wall. Fistulization provides a conduit for passage of gallstones, which may cause gallstone ileus. Patients with gallstone ileus can present with abdominal pain, nausea, and fever. However, physical examination would classically show high-pitched (tympanic) bowel sounds. In addition, even though cholescintigraphy is not a sensitive test for gallstone ileus, it would be expected to show communication between the gallbladder and intestinal tract rather than delayed uptake of radioactive tracer in the gallbladder. CT is the preferred imaging modality to confirm gallstone ileus and classically shows bowel obstruction with pneumobilia.
Image Description:

Cholecystoenteric fistula is an abnormal connection between the gallbladder lumen and the adjacent bowel (usually duodenum or stomach). The fistula creates a conduit for the passage of gallstones from the gallbladder into the bowel and for air from the bowel into the biliary system (i.e., pneumobilia), which can be seen on imaging.

Large gallstones can become lodged in the distal ileum (most commonly the ileocecal valve), causing gallstone ileus. Radiographic imaging typically shows signs of mechanical obstruction (distended bowel loops proximal to the obstruction) and the gallstone.

D) INCORRECT:

Infection with a hepatotropic virus (e.g., hepatitis A) can cause acute hepatitis. While acute hepatitis can manifest with right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and fever, it usually also manifests with markedly elevated liver function tests (e.g., AST, ALT), which are only mildly elevated in this patient. Moreover, a cholescintigraphy showing delayed uptake of radioactive tracer in the gallbladder suggests another etiology.

E) CORRECT:

Cholecystitis is usually caused by the passage of gallstones into the cystic duct. Cystic duct obstruction can lead to gallbladder inflammation with symptoms of right upper quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and fever, as seen in this patient. Cholescintigraphy (HIDA scan) typically shows delayed or absent uptake of radioactive tracer in the gallbladder; a HIDA scan is primarily used to diagnose cystic duct obstruction if RUQ ultrasound fails to show gallstones. In uncomplicated cholecystitis, cholestasis parameters (i.e., ALP, GGT, and bilirubin) are typically normal or only mildly elevated because there is usually no obstruction of the hepatic ducts or common bile duct.
Image Description:

The right and left hepatic ducts join to form the common hepatic duct. The cystic duct joins the common hepatic duct to form the common bile duct. The main pancreatic duct drains into the common bile duct. The common bile duct opens into the descending part of the duodenum.

F) INCORRECT:

Fibrosis of the common bile duct is seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis, which is a chronic inflammatory condition that can manifest with right upper quadrant pain and fever during acute episodes. However, patients with fibrosis of the common bile duct would be expected to have markedly elevated cholestasis parameters (i.e., ALP, GGT, and bilirubin). Moreover, cholescintigraphy would show impaired uptake of the radioactive tracer in the proximal bowel rather than delayed uptake of radioactive tracer in the gallbladder.
questions.hint: This patient has risk factors for gallstone disease (e.g., obesity, age > 40, female). Right upper quadrant pain, nausea, fever, and leukocytosis suggest acute cholecystitis.
